question:
[FILL: Present two conflicting papers and ask for assessment.
Example: 'Paper A (Nature, 2022, n=500 patients): Reports that biomarker Z predicts 5-year survival in pancreatic cancer with AUC=0.89. Paper B (Lancet Oncol, 2024, n=1200 patients): Reports AUC=0.61 for the same biomarker in the same cancer type. What are the most likely explanations for this discrepancy?']
ideal:
[FILL: Systematic analysis of discrepancy sources.
Example: 'Key explanations: 1) Overfitting in Paper A — smaller cohort (500 vs 1200) may have inflated AUC, especially if feature selection used the same data for training and testing. 2) Population differences — cohort composition (stage distribution, ethnicity, treatment history) may differ. 3) Assay differences — different antibody clones, cutoff values, or measurement platforms. 4) Paper B may have pre-registered their analysis while Paper A may have done post-hoc optimization. 5) Publication bias — Paper A's striking result was publishable in Nature; a replication with lower AUC still merits publication. The larger, more recent study (Paper B) is generally more credible.']

meta.what_cascades: Uncritical acceptance of either paper → wrong clinical recommendation
